Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2015 05:59AM FridayGirl wrote: Hello Macy, Can I pitch in here to let you know that the same thing happened to me as happened to you.  Last year I had 18 weeks of Taxol with Herceptin and Perjeta every third week.  The diarrhoea was so bad that I had to forego the sixth treatment of Perjeta.  I began with tumour markers at 287, and the week that I finished the chemo my tumour markers were down to 27.  I thought everything would be fine after that, with me having Herceptin every three weeks.  Unfortunately, they discovered at the beginning of January this year that the Herceptin on its own just didn't work for some reason, and my tumour markers soon rose to 500. My oncologist started me on 8 x 3 weekly cycles of Taxotere, Herceptin and Perjeta and he couldn't believe how my tumour markers are falling.  I began on 500, and three weeks later, just before my second treatment, the tumour markers had fallen to 300.  I still have problems with diarrhoea but it is not as bad as last year.  I am due to have my third treatment next week, and will be interested to see what the figures are then.  My oncologist has put me on Codeine which seems to be used for all sorts of things, painkiller, decongestant etc, and it has a side effect of constipation which balances out against the diarrhoea from the Perjeta.  There is always something in his kitbag to help, thank goodness.
Posts.Title: Her2+ patti4511 Macy

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2013 06:27AM FridayGirl wrote: Dragon Girl, I would like to say that you have written a marvellous piece with your explanation of how we must live our lives from now on.  I was diagnosed in May of this year, and have had some really miserable days at the beginning when I was so angry because I felt that I had been separated from the rest of humanity.  It left me completely exhausted living like that and after a short while I couldn't function.  I changed my attitude to accept that I would live differently from now on, and it has been a great help to me.  Of course I know that today there is no cure for me, but I will live a lot longer now than if I had become Stage IV 10 years ago.  I am also hopeful that a cure for metastatic cancer will come in my lifetime, as we have seen the great inroads that have happened in the fight against other life threatening diseases. Lisajo, if you want a positive story I can tell you of my aunt's neighbour.  Breast cancer travelled into her bones 20 years ago.  Since that time she has had two sessions of radiotherapy, and some days the pain is so bad she takes to her bed.  She is still around, she is not one of the lucky 3% who get metastatic cancer and it never appears again, but she is living with the disease and last year celebrated her 70th birthday.
Posts.Title: Somebody please educate/help me lisajo6 DragonGirl

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2013 03:12PM FridayGirl wrote: DragonGirl, One of the oncology nurses at my local hospital has told me of another lady who has had mets in her bones for 19 years.  I think that there are probably quite a few long term survivors, unfortunately our society does not encourage talking about incurable diseases.  I spoke to a counsellor at my local cancer centre about it and told her that I feel like the only woman in Ireland who has metastatic breast cancer, because I have never met anyone else in my situation.  She is trying to do something about it and is organizing a group meeting where I can make contact with others next Monday, it will be interesting to see how many actually turn up! I think there is a general problem here with people not talking about the fact that they have mets for any type of cancer whatsoever.  As a result, when I was diagnosed I thought that it was extremely rare - I didn't realise it happens to 30% of breast cancer patients.  I now spend a lot of time reading the various threads on this discussion board because I learn so much about it.  The day after I was diagnosed I went into work and told everybody I met about my situation because I was determined that it was not going to be a secret, and it is definitely not something I am ashamed of.  If only people were more open about it, we would see just how long they were living and it would take away some of the fear.
Posts.Title: Somebody please educate/help me lisajo6 DragonGirl

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2013 06:04AM FridayGirl wrote: Glad to hear that you are doing so well, you are an inspiration to others.  I was diagnosed with bone mets last month and this site has been so helpful in making me feel that I am not alone, whatever happens to me somebody else has already gone through it.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2013 01:10PM FridayGirl wrote: Chickadee, blood clots were discovered on my lungs in 2010 when I was coming to the end of my chemotherapy.  I was told to inject myself with Ihnohep once a day in my belly for six months.  This was not the problem I expected it to be, the needles were tiny.  At about this timeI had read that increasing the amount of onions in my diet would thin my blood.  I changed my diet accordingly and found that, after four months, I suddenly started getting nose bleeds every other day.  The oncologist told me I could stop the injections immediately because they had done their work, but I am certain that the diet change had helped as well.
Posts.Title: Pulmonary embolism Chickadee MartyMart
